questions.question: What is 'cybersquatting'?
options: Registering a domain in bad faith to profit from another’s trademark
questions.explanation: Cybersquatting means registering or using a domain name similar to a trademark with the intent to sell or misuse it.

questions.question: Which body handles disputes for '.IN' domain names?
questions.explanation: The INDRP (IN Domain Name Dispute Resolution Policy) handles disputes for .IN domain names under NIXI.

questions.question: The international system for resolving domain disputes is called:
questions.explanation: UDRP (Uniform Domain-Name Dispute-Resolution Policy) is managed by WIPO for global domain disputes.

questions.question: Cybersquatters usually register domains to:
options: Sell the domain at a higher price or mislead users
questions.explanation: Cybersquatters act in bad faith — often to sell domains back to brand owners or divert web traffic.

questions.question: Keyword advertising involves:
options: Buying competitor’s brand name as a keyword in ads
Using random words to boost ranking
questions.explanation: Keyword advertising refers to using a competitor’s trademark in paid search ads, e.g., on Google Ads.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of cybersquatting?
options: Registering your personal name as a domain
Creating an official website for a college project
Buying a domain for your startup
questions.explanation: Registering a domain like 'tata-motors-india.com' to mislead or sell it is classic cybersquatting.

questions.question: Who administers the UDRP system?
questions.explanation: The World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) manages the UDRP domain dispute mechanism.

questions.question: Under Indian law, cybersquatting can also amount to:
questions.explanation: Cybersquatting infringes on trademarks and can constitute 'passing off' under the Trade Marks Act.

questions.question: Which organization manages '.IN' domain registrations in India?
questions.explanation: The National Internet Exchange of India (NIXI) oversees the '.IN' registry and the INDRP dispute process.

questions.question: Comparative advertising is lawful when:
options: It compares fairly without misleading consumers
questions.explanation: Comparative ads are legal if they are factual and not deceptive about competitors’ products.

questions.question: Under UDRP, a complainant must prove that:
options: The domain was registered and used in bad faith
questions.explanation: UDRP requires proof that the domain is identical or confusingly similar to a mark and was registered in bad faith.

questions.question: What is the main difference between UDRP and INDRP?
options: INDRP covers .IN domains; UDRP covers international domains
UDRP is only for government sites
UDRP is faster but limited to India
questions.explanation: INDRP applies to '.IN' country-code domains, while UDRP applies to global generic top-level domains (like .com, .org).

questions.question: Using a competitor’s trademark as a Google Ad keyword is:
options: Legal if not misleading or implying endorsement
questions.explanation: Keyword advertising can be allowed if it doesn’t cause consumer confusion or false association.

questions.question: Which Indian company has faced cybersquatting issues with its brand name?
questions.explanation: Tata and other large brands have dealt with cybersquatters registering misleading domain names.

questions.question: Keyword advertising disputes are mainly about:
questions.explanation: The key issue is whether consumers are misled into thinking the ad is from the competitor’s brand.

questions.question: Comparative ads are *deceptive* when they:
questions.explanation: Deceptive ads go beyond fair comparison — they mislead or disparage competitors’ products.

questions.question: What happens when a cybersquatter loses a domain dispute under INDRP?
options: They pay damages to the government
They must transfer or cancel the domain name
They can keep the domain if they apologize
They are banned from the internet
questions.explanation: The INDRP panel may order the transfer or cancellation of the disputed domain.

questions.question: Which legal concept protects consumers from deceptive keyword ads?
questions.explanation: Using a competitor’s trademark misleadingly in ads can amount to 'passing off'.

questions.question: Which global body oversees implementation of the UDRP policy?
questions.explanation: The UDRP operates under ICANN’s oversight, with WIPO acting as a dispute-resolution provider.

questions.question: A comparative ad showing true facts about price difference is:
questions.explanation: Truthful, fair comparisons that don’t mislead are allowed under comparative advertising principles.

questions.question: Which landmark case dealt with keyword advertising and trademarks?
questions.explanation: The 'Google France v. Louis Vuitton' case clarified liability in keyword advertising disputes in the EU.

questions.question: What’s a key sign of 'bad faith' in domain registration?
options: Domain matches a famous trademark and is offered for sale
questions.explanation: Offering a domain identical to a known trademark for sale indicates bad faith under UDRP/INDRP.

questions.question: A company registers 'amazzon.in' and redirects it to ads — this is:
questions.explanation: Typo-squatting involves registering misspelled domains to exploit traffic from user mistakes.

questions.question: Cybersquatting primarily violates which right of trademark owners?
options: Right to exclusive commercial use of their brand name online
Right to renew marks every 10 years
questions.explanation: It interferes with the exclusive right of trademark owners to use their mark in commerce, including on the internet.

questions.question: Keyword bidding on a rival’s brand name is illegal when:
options: It causes consumer confusion or implies endorsement
The rival is in another country
questions.explanation: Using competitor marks in keywords becomes illegal when it misleads users into believing endorsement or affiliation.
